data.question: What is the primary moiety contained in the four synthesized porous heterometallic coordination polymers?
Which reactions are the synthesized compounds capable of catalyzing efficiently?
What strategy was used to synthesize the heterometallic coordination polymers?
What is the role of the Ln3+ cations in the synthesized compounds?
data.answer: Ln3+ acts as linker-bridging metal centre

data.question: What is the coordination mode of the Pd atoms in the synthesized compounds?
What is the solvent used for the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction optimization?
What is the effect of electron-donating substituents on the reaction rate in the Pd–Ln catalyst system?
How does the presence of electron-withdrawing groups affect the Heck reaction?
data.answer: Beneficial to the occurrence of Heck reaction

data.question: What method was used to confirm the heterogeneous nature of the catalysis?
What was the yield of biphenyl obtained using bromobenzene and Pd–Sm as the model catalytic system?
What is the role of the Pd(diimine)Cl2 moiety in the synthesized compounds?
What is the effect of heating compound 1 at 120 1C under vacuum for 6 h?
data.answer: Formation of open framework 10 with permanent microporosity

data.question: True or False: The synthesized compounds are homogeneous catalysts.
True or False: The Ln3+ cations significantly influence the catalytic property of the synthesized compounds.
True or False: The synthesized compounds show remarkable versatility in catalyzing only Suzuki–Miyaura reactions.
True or False: The Pd–Ln catalysts are capable of catalyzing Heck reactions with high yields.
True or False: The synthesized compounds are not stable after catalytic reactions.
True or False: Chlorobenzene compounds are easily activated in the Heck reaction.
True or False: The synthesized compounds can be reused in catalytic reactions without significant loss of activity.
True or False: The synthesized compounds are soluble in common organic solvents.
